speaker: YOUNG ELIZABETH (O.S.)
dialogue: Yo, ho, yo, ho, a pirate's life for me Yo, ho, yo, ho, it's a pirate's life for me...

speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogue: ...drink up me hearties, yo, ho...

speaker: GIBBS
dialogue: Quiet, missy! Cursed pirates sail these waters. You want to call 'em down on us?

speaker: NORRINGTON
dialogue: Mr. Gibbs.

speaker: NORRINGTON
dialogue: That will do.

speaker: GIBBS
dialogue: She was singing about pirates.

speaker: NORRINGTON
dialogue: Consider them marked. On your way.

speaker: GIBBS
dialogue: 'Aye, Captain. Bad luck to have a woman on board, too. Even a mini'ture one.

speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogue: I think it would be rather exciting to meet a pirate.

speaker: NORRINGTON
dialogue: Think again, Miss Swan. Vile and dissolute creatures, the lot of them. I intend to see to it that any man who sails under a pirate flag, or wears a pirates brand, gets what he deserves: a short drop and a sudden stop.

speaker: SWANN
dialogue: Captain Norrington... I appreciate your fervor, but I am concerned about the effect this subject will have on my daughter.

speaker: NORRINGTON
dialogue: My apologies, Governor.

speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogue: Actually, I find it all fascinating.

speaker: SWANN
dialogue: And that's what concerns me. Elizabeth, dear... we will be landing in Port Royal very soon, and beginning our new lives. Wouldn't it be wonderful if we comport ourselves as befits our class and station?

speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogue: Yes, father.

speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogue: I still think it would be exciting to meet a pirate...

speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogue: Look! A boy! In the water!

speaker: NORRINGTON
dialogue: Man overboard!

speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogue: Boy overboard!

speaker: NORRINGTON
dialogue: Fetch a hook! Haul him out of there!

speaker: NORRINGTON
dialogue: He's still breathing.

speaker: SWANN
dialogue: Where did he come from?

speaker: GIBBS
dialogue: Mary mother of God...

speaker: SWANN
dialogue: What happened here?

speaker: NORRINGTON
dialogue: An explosion in the powder magazine. Merchant vessels run heavily armed.

speaker: GIBBS
dialogue: Lot of good it did them... Everyone's thinking it! I'm just saying it! Pirates!

speaker: SWANN
dialogue: There is no proof of that. It could have been an accident. Captain, these men were protection. If there is even the slightest chance one of those poor devils is still alive, we cannot abandon them!

speaker: NORRINGTON
dialogue: Of course not, Governor. Come about and strike the sails! Unlash the boats! Gunnery crew... jackets off the cannons! Hope for the best... prepare for the worst. Move the boy aft. We'll need the deck clear.

speaker: SWANN
dialogue: Elizabeth, I want you to accompany the boy. He's in your charge now. You'll watch over him?

speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogue: My name is Elizabeth Swann.

speaker: WILL
dialogue: Will Turner.

speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogue: I'm watching over you, Will.

speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogue: You're a pirate.

speaker: NORRINGTON
dialogue: Did he speak?

speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogue: His name is Will Turner -- that's all I found out.

speaker: NORRINGTON
dialogue: Very good.

speaker: SWANN (O.S.)
dialogue: Elizabeth? Is everything all right? Are you decent?

speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogue: Yes -- yes.

speaker: SWANN
dialogue: Still abed at this hour? It's a beautiful day!

speaker: SWANN
dialogue: I have a gift for you.

speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogue: It's -- beautiful. May I inquire as to the occasion?

speaker: SWANN
dialogue: Is an occasion necessary for a father to dote upon his daughter with gifts?

speaker: SWANN
dialogue: Although... I did think you could wear it to the ceremony today.

speaker: ELIZABETH (O.S.)
dialogue: Ceremony?

speaker: SWANN
dialogue: Captain Norrington's promotion ceremony.

speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogue: I knew it.

speaker: SWANN
dialogue: Or, rather, Commodore Norrington... a fine gentleman, don't you think? He fancies you, you know.

speaker: SWANN
dialogue: Elizabeth? How's it coming?

speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogue: Difficult... to say.

speaker: SWANN (O.S.)
dialogue: I'm told that dress is the very latest fashion in London.

speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogue: Women in London must have learned to not breath.

speaker: BUTLER
dialogue: Governor? A caller is here for you.

speaker: SWANN
dialogue: Ah, Mr. Turner! It's good to see you again!

speaker: WILL
dialogue: Good day, sir. I have your order.

speaker: WILL
dialogue: The blade is folded steel. That's gold filigree laid into the handle. If I may --

speaker: WILL
dialogue: Perfectly balanced. The tang is nearly the full width of the blade..

speaker: SWANN
dialogue: Impressive... very impressive. Commodore Norrington will be pleased, I'm sure. Do pass my compliments on to your master.

speaker: WILL
dialogue: I shall. A craftsman is always pleased to hear his work is appreciated --

speaker: SWANN
dialogue: Elizabeth! You look stunning!

speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogue: Will! It's so good to see you!

speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogue: I dreamt about you last night.

speaker: SWANN
dialogue: Elizabeth, this is hardly appropriate --

speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogue: About the day we met. Do you remember?

speaker: WILL
dialogue: I could never forget it, Miss Swann.

speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogue: Will, how many times must I ask you to call me 'Elizabeth'?

speaker: WILL
dialogue: At least once more, Miss Swann. As always.

speaker: SWANN
dialogue: Well said! There's a boy who understands propriety. Now, we must be going.

speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogue: Good day, Mr. Turner.

speaker: WILL
dialogue: Good day.

speaker: WILL
dialogue: Elizabeth.

speaker: SWANN
dialogue: Dear, I do hope you demonstrate a bit more decorum in front of Commodore Norrington. After all, it is only through his efforts that Port Royal has become at all civilized.

speaker: HARBORMASTER
dialogue: If you're out rolling scuppers in this tub, you're either incredibly brave or incredibly stupid.

speaker: JACK
dialogue: It's remarkable how often those two traits coincide.

speaker: HARBORMASTER
dialogue: It's a shilling for the dock space, and you're going to have to give me your name.

speaker: JACK
dialogue: What do you say to three shillings, and we forget the name?

speaker: HARBORMASTER
dialogue: Welcome to Port Royal, Mr. Smith.

speaker: MURTOGG
dialogue: This dock is off-limits to civilians.

speaker: JACK
dialogue: Sorry, I didn't know.

speaker: JACK
dialogue: Some sort of to-do up at the fort, eh? You two weren't invited?

speaker: MURTOGG
dialogue: No... someone has to make sure this dock stays off-limits to civilians.

speaker: JACK
dialogue: This must be some important boat.

speaker: MULLROY
dialogue: Ship.

speaker: JACK
dialogue: Ship.

speaker: MURTOGG
dialogue: Captain Norrington's made it his flagship. He'll use it to hunt down the last dregs of piracy on the Spanish Lake.

speaker: MULLROY
dialogue: Commodore.

speaker: MURTOGG
dialogue: Right. Commodore Norrington.

speaker: JACK
dialogue: That's a fine goal, I'm sure... But it seems to me a ship like that -- -- makes this one here just a wee superfluous.

speaker: MURTOGG
dialogue: Oh, the Dauntless is the power in these waters, true enough -- but there's no ship that can match the Interceptor for speed.

speaker: JACK
dialogue: That so? I've heard of one, supposed to be fast, nigh uncatchable... the Black Pearl?

speaker: MULLROY
dialogue: There's no real ship as can match the Interceptor.

speaker: MURTOGG
dialogue: The Black Pearl is a real ship.

speaker: MULLROY
dialogue: No, it's not.

speaker: MURTOGG
dialogue: Yes it is. I've seen it.

speaker: MULLROY
dialogue: You've seen it?

speaker: MURTOGG
dialogue: Yes.

speaker: MULLROY
dialogue: You've seen the Black Pearl?

speaker: MURTOGG
dialogue: Yes.

speaker: MULLROY
dialogue: You haven't seen it.

speaker: MURTOGG
dialogue: Yes, I have.

speaker: MULLROY
dialogue: You've seen a ship with black sails that's crewed by the damned and captained by a man so evil that hell itself spat him back out?

speaker: MULLROY
dialogue: No.

speaker: MURTOGG
dialogue: But I've seen a ship with black sails.

speaker: MULLROY
dialogue: Oh, and no ship that's not crewed by the damned and captained by a man so evil hell itself spat him back out could possibly have black sails and therefore couldn't possibly be any ship other than the Black Pearl. Is that what you're saying?

speaker: MULLROY
dialogue: Like I said, there's no real ship as can match -- Hey!

speaker: MULLROY
dialogue: You!

speaker: MULLROY
dialogue: Get away from there! You don't have permission to be aboard there!

speaker: JACK
dialogue: I'm sorry. It's just such a pretty boat. Ship.

speaker: MURTOGG
dialogue: What's your name?

speaker: JACK
dialogue: Smith.

speaker: MULLROY
dialogue: What's your business in Port Royal, 'Mr. Smith' ?

speaker: MURTOGG
dialogue: And no lies!

speaker: JACK
dialogue: None? Very well. You've rumbled me. I confess: I intend to commandeer one of these ships, pick up a crew in Tortuga, and go out on the account, do a little honest pirating.

speaker: MURTOGG
dialogue: I said, no lies.

speaker: MULLROY
dialogue: I think he's telling the truth.

speaker: MURTOGG
dialogue: He's not telling the truth.

speaker: MULLROY
dialogue: He may be.

speaker: MURTOGG
dialogue: If he were telling the truth he wouldn't have told us.

speaker: JACK
dialogue: Unless, of course, he knew you wouldn't believe the truth if he told it to you.

speaker: NORRINGTON
dialogue: May I have a moment?

speaker: NORRINGTON
dialogue: You look lovely. Elizabeth.

speaker: NORRINGTON
dialogue: I apologize if I seem forward -- but I must speak my mind. This promotion confirms that I have accomplished the goals I set for myself in my career. But it also casts into sharp relief that which I have not achieved. The thing all men most require: a marriage to a fine woman. You have become a fine woman, Elizabeth.

speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogue: I can't breathe.

speaker: NORRINGTON
dialogue: I'm a bit nervous, myself --

speaker: NORRINGTON
dialogue: Elizabeth!

speaker: NORRINGTON
dialogue: ELIZABETH!

speaker: GILLETTE
dialogue: The rocks, sir! It's a miracle she missed them!

speaker: JACK
dialogue: Aren't you going to save her?

speaker: MULLROY
dialogue: I can't swim.

speaker: JACK
dialogue: Sailors.

speaker: JACK
dialogue: Fine.

speaker: JACK
dialogue: Don't lose these.

speaker: MULLROY
dialogue: Not breathing.

speaker: JACK
dialogue: Move.

speaker: MULLROY
dialogue: I never would have thought of that.

speaker: JACK
dialogue: Clearly, you've never been to Singapore.

speaker: JACK
dialogue: Where did you get this?

speaker: NORRINGTON
dialogue: On your feet.

speaker: SWANN
dialogue: Elizabeth! Are you all right?

speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogue: Yes -- yes, I'm fine -- Commodore Norrington, do you intend to kill my rescuer?

speaker: NORRINGTON
dialogue: I believe thanks are in order.

speaker: NORRINGTON
dialogue: Had a brush-up with the East India Trading Company, did you... pirate?

speaker: NORRINGTON
dialogue: Keep your guns on him, men. Gillette, fetch some irons.

speaker: NORRINGTON
dialogue: Well, well... Jack Sparrow, isn't it?

speaker: JACK
dialogue: Captain Jack Sparrow. If you please.

speaker: NORRINGTON
dialogue: I don't see your ship -- Captain.

speaker: MURTOGG
dialogue: He said he'd come to commandeer one.

speaker: MULLROY
dialogue: I told you he was telling the truth. These are his, sir.

speaker: NORRINGTON
dialogue: Extra powder, but no additional shot.

speaker: NORRINGTON
dialogue: It doesn't bear true.

speaker: NORRINGTON
dialogue: I half-expected it to be made of wood.

speaker: NORRINGTON
dialogue: Taking stock: you've got a pistol with only one shot, a compass that doesn't point north... and no ship. You are without a doubt the worst pirate I have ever heard of.

speaker: JACK
dialogue: Ah, but you have heard of me.

speaker: NORRINGTON
dialogue: Carefully, lieutenant.

speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogue: Commodore, I must protest. Pirate or not, this man saved my life.

speaker: NORRINGTON
dialogue: One good deed is not enough to redeem a man of a lifetime of wickedness.

speaker: JACK
dialogue: But it seems to be enough to condemn him.

speaker: NORRINGTON
dialogue: Indeed.

speaker: JACK
dialogue: Finally.

speaker: JACK
dialogue: Commodore Norrington... my pistol and belt, please.

speaker: JACK
dialogue: Commodore!

speaker: JACK
dialogue: Elizabeth -- it is Elizabeth?

speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogue: Miss Swann.

speaker: JACK
dialogue: Miss Swann, if you'll be so kind?

speaker: JACK
dialogue: Now, if you'll be very kind?

speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogue: You are despicable.

speaker: JACK
dialogue: I saved your life; now you've saved mine. We're square.

speaker: JACK
dialogue: Gentleman... m' lady... you will always remember this as the day you almost caught Captain Jack Sparrow.

speaker: NORRINGTON
dialogue: On his heels! Gillette, bring a squad down from the fort! Elizabeth, are you --

speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogue: Yes, I'm all right, I'm fine! Go capture him.

speaker: SWANN
dialogue: Here, dear... you should wear this.

speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogue: Thank you, Father... and let that be the last of your fashion advice, please.

speaker: WILL
dialogue: Right where I left you.

speaker: WILL
dialogue: Not where I left you.

speaker: WILL
dialogue: You're the one they're hunting. The pirate.

speaker: JACK
dialogue: You look familiar... Have I ever threatened you before?

speaker: WILL
dialogue: I've made a point of avoiding familiarity with pirates.

speaker: JACK
dialogue: Ah. Then it would be a shame to put a black mark on your record. So if you'll excuse me...

speaker: JACK
dialogue: Do you think this is wise, boy? Crossing blades with a pirate?

speaker: WILL
dialogue: You threatened Miss Swann.

speaker: JACK
dialogue: Only a little.

speaker: JACK
dialogue: You know what you're doing, I'll give you that... Excellent form... But how's your footwork? If I step here --

speaker: JACK
dialogue: Very good! And if I step again, you step again... And so we circle, circle, like dogs we circle...

speaker: JACK
dialogue: Ta!

speaker: JACK
dialogue: That's a good trick. Except, once again, you are between me and the way out. And now you have no weapon.

speaker: JACK
dialogue: Who makes all these?

speaker: WILL
dialogue: I do. And I practice with them. At least three hours a day.

speaker: JACK
dialogue: You need to find yourself a girl. Or maybe the reason you practice three hours a day is you've found one -- but can't get her?

speaker: WILL
dialogue: No. I practice three hours a day so that when I meet a pirate... I can kill him.

speaker: WILL
dialogue: You cheated.

speaker: JACK
dialogue: Pirate.

speaker: JACK
dialogue: Move away.

speaker: WILL
dialogue: No.

speaker: JACK
dialogue: Move!

speaker: WILL
dialogue: No. I can not just step aside and let you escape.

speaker: JACK
dialogue: You're lucky, boy -- this shot's not meant for you.

speaker: NORRINGTON
dialogue: Excellent work, Mister Brown. You've aided in the capture of a dangerous fugitive.

speaker: BROWN
dialogue: Just doing my civic duty.

speaker: NORRINGTON
dialogue: I believe you will always remember this as the day Captain Jack Sparrow almost escaped.

speaker: BROWN
dialogue: That ratter broke my bottle.

speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogue: Nice and toasty. Thank you, Estrellia.

speaker: PRISONER
dialogue: Come here, boy... Want a nice, juicy bone?

speaker: JACK
dialogue: You can keep doing that forever, that dog's never going to move.

speaker: PRISONER
dialogue: Excuse us if we ain't resigned ourselves to the gallows just yet.

speaker: SWANN
dialogue: Has my daughter given you an answer yet?

speaker: NORRINGTON
dialogue: No. She hasn't.

speaker: SWANN
dialogue: Well, she had a taxing day... Ghastly weather tonight.

speaker: NORRINGTON
dialogue: Bleak. Very bleak.

speaker: SWANN
dialogue: What was that?

speaker: NORRINGTON
dialogue: Cannon fire!

speaker: JACK
dialogue: I know those guns!

speaker: JACK
dialogue: It's the Black Pearl.

speaker: PRISONER
dialogue: The Black Pearl? I've heard stories... she's been preying on ships and settlements for near ten years... and never leaves any survivors.

speaker: JACK
dialogue: There are a lot of stories about the Black Pearl.

speaker: NORRINGTON
dialogue: Governor! Barricade yourself in my office! That's an order!

speaker: NORRINGTON
dialogue: They've flanked us! Men! Swords and pistols!

speaker: PINTEL
dialogue: Up there!

speaker: ESTRELLA
dialogue: Miss Elizabeth?

speaker: ESTRELLA
dialogue: Are they come to kidnap you, miss? The daughter of the governor would be very valuable.

speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogue: Listen, Estrella -- they haven't seen you. Hide, and first chance, run for the fort.

speaker: PINTEL
dialogue: We know you're here, poppet. Come out and we promise we won't hurt you.

speaker: PINTEL
dialogue: We will find you, poppet... You've got something of ours, and it calls to us!

speaker: PINTEL (O.S.)
dialogue: The gold calls to us!

speaker: PINTEL
dialogue: Hello, poppet.

speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogue: Please, no...

speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogue: Par... Parlay!

speaker: PINTEL
dialogue: What?

speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogue: Parlay! I invoke the right of parlay! According to the Code of the Brethren, set down by the pirates Morgan and Bartholomew, you must take me to your Captain!

speaker: PINTEL
dialogue: I know the code.

speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogue: If an adversary demands parley, you can do them no harm until the parlay is complete.

speaker: PINTEL
dialogue: It would appear, so do you.

speaker: SMOLDERING PIRATE
dialogue: To blazes with the code!

speaker: PINTEL
dialogue: She wants to be taken to the Captain, and she'll go without a fuss.

speaker: PINTEL
dialogue: We must honor the code.

speaker: PRISIONER
dialogue: Praise be!

speaker: PRISONER
dialogue: My sympathies, friend -- you've no manner of luck at all!

speaker: JACK
dialogue: It's all right, doggie... come here, boy. Come here, Spot. Rover. Fido?

speaker: JACK
dialogue: What's the matter, boy?

speaker: TWIGG
dialogue: This isn't the armory.

speaker: KOEHLER
dialogue: Well, well... Look what we have here, Twigg. It's Captain Sparrow.

speaker: TWIGG
dialogue: Huh. Last time I saw you, you were all alone on a God-forsaken island, shrinking into the distance. I'd heard you'd gotten off, but I didn't believe it.

speaker: KOEHLER
dialogue: Did you sprout little wings and flyaway?

speaker: TWIGG
dialogue: His fortunes aren't improved much.

speaker: JACK
dialogue: Worry about your own fortunes. The lowest circle of hell is reserved for betrayers... and mutineers.

speaker: JACK
dialogue: You are cursed.

speaker: JACK
dialogue: The stories are true.

speaker: KOEHLER
dialogue: You know nothing of hell.

speaker: BOSUN
dialogue: I didn't know we was taking captives.

speaker: PINTEL
dialogue: She's invoked the right of parlay... with Captain Barbossa.

speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogue: I am here to --

speaker: BOSUN
dialogue: You'll speak when spoken to!

speaker: BARBOSSA
dialogue: And you'll not lay a hand on those under the protection of parlay!

speaker: BOSUN
dialogue: Aye, sir.

speaker: BARBOSSA
dialogue: My apologies, miss. As you were saying, before you were so rudely interrupted?

speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogue: Captain Barbossa... I have come to negotiate the cessation of hostilities against Port Royal.

speaker: BARBOSSA
dialogue: There was a lot of long words in there, miss, and we're not but humble pirates. What is it you want?

speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogue: I want you to leave. And never come back.

speaker: BARBOSSA
dialogue: I am disinclined to acquiesce to your request. Means 'no.'

speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogue: Very well.

speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogue: I'll drop it!

speaker: BARBOSSA
dialogue: My holds are bursting with swag. That bit of shine matters to me... Why?

speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogue: Because it's what you're searching for. You've been searching for it for years. I recognize this ship. I saw it eight years ago, when we made the crossing from England.

speaker: BARBOSSA
dialogue: Did you, now?

speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogue: Fine. I suppose if this is worthless, there's no reason to keep it.

speaker: BARBOSSA
dialogue: NO!

speaker: BARBOSSA
dialogue: You have a name, missy?

speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogue: Elizabeth -- Turner. I'm a maid in the governor's household.

speaker: BARBOSSA
dialogue: You've got sand, for a maid.

speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogue: Thank you, sir.

speaker: BARBOSSA
dialogue: And how does a maid come to own a trinket such as that? A family heirloom, perhaps?

speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogue: Of course. I didn't steal it, if that's what you mean.

speaker: BARBOSSA
dialogue: No, no, nothing like that. Very well. You hand that over, we'll put your town to our rudder and ne'er return.

speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogue: Can I trust you?

speaker: BARBOSSA
dialogue: It's you who invoked the parlay! Believe me, Miss, you'd best hand it over, now... or these be the last friendly words you'll hear!

speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogue: Our bargain...?

speaker: BOSUN
dialogue: Still the guns, and stow 'em! Signal the men, set the flags, and make good to clear port!

speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogue: Wait! You must return me to shore! According to the rules of the Order of the Brethren --

speaker: BARBOSSA
dialogue: First. Your return to shore was not part of our negotiations nor our agreement, and so I 'must' do nothing. Secondly: you must be a pirate for the pirate's code to apply. And you're not. And thirdly... The code is more what you'd call guidelines than actual rules. Welcome aboard the Black Pearl, Miss Turner.

speaker: WILL
dialogue: Miss Swann! Elizabeth!

speaker: WILL
dialogue: They've taken her! They've taken Elizabeth!

speaker: NORRINGTON
dialogue: We're aware of the situation.

speaker: WILL
dialogue: We have to hunt them down -- and save her!

speaker: SWANN
dialogue: Where do you propose we start? If you have any information that concerns my daughter, then share it! If anyone does, tell me! Leave, Mr. Turner.

speaker: MURTOGG
dialogue: That Jack Sparrow... he talked about the Black Pearl.

speaker: MULLROY
dialogue: Mentioned it, is more what he did.

speaker: MURTOGG
dialogue: Still --

speaker: WILL
dialogue: We can ask him where it is -- maybe he can lead us to it!

speaker: SWANN
dialogue: That pirate tried to kill my daughter. We could never trust a word he said!

speaker: WILL
dialogue: We could strike a bargain --

speaker: NORRINGTON
dialogue: No. The pirates who invaded this fort left Sparrow locked in his cell. Ergo, he is not their ally, and therefore of no value. We will determine their most likely course, and launch a search mission that sails with the tide.

speaker: WILL
dialogue: That's not good enough. This is Elizabeth's life!

speaker: NORRINGTON
dialogue: Mr. Turner, this is not the time for rash actions. Do not make the mistake of thinking you are the only man here who loves Elizabeth. Now, go home.

speaker: WILL
dialogue: Are you familiar with that ship? The Black Pearl?

speaker: JACK
dialogue: Somewhat.

speaker: WILL
dialogue: Where does it make berth?

speaker: JACK
dialogue: Surely you've heard the stories? The Black Pearl sails from the dreaded Isla de Mureta... an island that cannot be found -- except by those who already know where it is.

speaker: WILL
dialogue: The ship's real enough. So its anchorage must be a real place. Where is it?

speaker: JACK
dialogue: Why ask me?

speaker: WILL
dialogue: Because you're a pirate.

speaker: JACK
dialogue: And you want to turn pirate yourself?

speaker: WILL
dialogue: Never. They took Miss Swann.

speaker: JACK
dialogue: So it is that you found a girl. Well, if you're intending to brave all and hasten to her rescue and so win fair lady's heart, you'll have to do it alone. I see no profit in it for me.

speaker: WILL
dialogue: I can get you out of here.

speaker: JACK
dialogue: How? The key's run off.

speaker: WILL
dialogue: I helped build these cells. Those are hook-and-ring hinges. The proper application of strength, the door'll lift free. Just calls for the right lever and fulcrum...

speaker: JACK
dialogue: Your name is Turner.

speaker: WILL
dialogue: Yes. Will Turner.

speaker: JACK
dialogue: Will Turner... I'll tell you what, Mr. Turner. I've changed my mind. You spring me from this cell, and on pain of death, I'll get you to the Black Pearl. Do we have an accord?

speaker: WILL
dialogue: Agreed.

speaker: JACK
dialogue: Agreed!

speaker: WILL
dialogue: Someone will have heard that. Hurry.

speaker: JACK
dialogue: Not without my effects.

speaker: WILL
dialogue: We need to go!

speaker: WILL
dialogue: Why are you bothering with that?

speaker: JACK
dialogue: My business, Will. As for your business -- one question, or there's no use going. This girl -- what does she mean to you? How far are you willing to go to save her?

speaker: WILL
dialogue: I'd die for her.

speaker: JACK
dialogue: Good.

speaker: JACK (O.S.)
dialogue: Ah, now there's a lovely sight!

speaker: JACK
dialogue: I knew the Harbormaster wouldn't report her. Honest men are slaves to their conscience, and there's no predicting 'em. But you can always trust a dishonest man to stay that way...

speaker: JACK
dialogue: Come aboard.

speaker: WILL
dialogue: I haven't set foot off dry land I was twelve, when the ship I was on exploded. It's been a sound policy.

speaker: JACK
dialogue: No worries there. She's far more likely to rot out from under us.

speaker: JACK
dialogue: Besides, we are about to better our prospects considerably.

speaker: WILL
dialogue: We're going to steal a ship? That ship?

speaker: JACK
dialogue: Commandeer. We're going to commandeer a ship. Nautical term.

speaker: WILL
dialogue: It's still against the law.

speaker: JACK
dialogue: So's breaking a man out of jail. Face it, Will: you may say you'll never be a pirate, but you're off to a rip-roaring start. My advice -- smile and enjoy it.

speaker: WILL
dialogue: This is either crazy, or brilliant.

speaker: JACK
dialogue: Remarkable how often those two traits coincide.

speaker: JACK
dialogue: Everybody stay calm. We're taking over the ship!

speaker: WILL
dialogue: Aye! Avast!

speaker: GILLETTE
dialogue: You're serious about this.

speaker: JACK
dialogue: Dead serious.

speaker: GILLETTE
dialogue: You understand this ship cannot be crewed by only two men. You'll never make it out of the bay.

speaker: JACK
dialogue: We'll see about that.

speaker: GILLETTE
dialogue: Sir, I'll not see any of my men killed or wounded in this foolish enterprise.

speaker: JACK
dialogue: Fine by me. We brought you a nice little boat, so you can all get back to shore, safe and sound.

speaker: GILLETTE
dialogue: Agreed. You have the momentary advantage, sir. But I will see you smile from the yard arm sir.

speaker: JACK
dialogue: As likely as not. Will, short up the anchor, we've got ourselves a ship!

speaker: JACK
dialogue: A little help?

speaker: MURTOGG
dialogue: I can't believe he's doing this.

speaker: MULLROY
dialogue: You didn't believe he was telling the truth, either.

speaker: GILLETTE
dialogue: Do you have any idea, boy, what you're doing?

speaker: WILL
dialogue: No.

speaker: JACK
dialogue: Lookee there, mate! We're underway!

speaker: SWANN
dialogue: Commodore --

speaker: NORRINGTON
dialogue: A moment.

speaker: SWANN
dialogue: But --

speaker: NORRINGTON
dialogue: Please.

speaker: SWANN
dialogue: Dammit, man, it appears someone is stealing your ship!

speaker: NORRINGTON
dialogue: Rash, Turner, too rash.

speaker: NORRINGTON
dialogue: That is, without doubt, the worst pirate I have ever seen.

speaker: WILL
dialogue: They're coming!

speaker: NORRINGTON
dialogue: Search every cabin, every hold, down to the bilges!

speaker: JACK
dialogue: Can you swim? Can. You. Swim?

speaker: SENTRY
dialogue: Of course, sir. Like a fish. I grew up summers living in Dover, with my uncle --

speaker: JACK
dialogue: Good.

speaker: NORRINGTON
dialogue: Sailors! Back to the Interceptor!

speaker: JACK
dialogue: Thank you, Commodore, for getting our ship ready to make way! We'd've had a hard time of it by ourselves!

speaker: NORRINGTON
dialogue: Raise the sails.

speaker: GILLETTE
dialogue: The wind is quarter from astern... by the time we're underway, we'll never catch them.

speaker: NORRINGTON
dialogue: We need only to come about, to put them in range of the long nines.

speaker: GILLETTE
dialogue: Hands! Come about! Jackets off the cannons! We are to fire on our own ship?

speaker: NORRINGTON
dialogue: Better to see it at the bottom of the sea than in the hands of a pirate.

speaker: STEERSMAN
dialogue: Captain, there's a problem.

speaker: STEERSMAN
dialogue: He's disabled the rudder chain, sir.

speaker: NORRINGTON
dialogue: So it would seem.

speaker: GILLETTE
dialogue: He's got to be the best pirate I've ever seen.

speaker: NORRINGTON
dialogue: So it would seem.

speaker: PINTEL
dialogue: You'll be dining with the Captain, and he requests you wear this.

speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogue: Tell the captain that I am disinclined to acquiesce to his request.

speaker: PINTEL
dialogue: He said you say that! He also said if that be the case, you'll be dining with the crew, and you'll be naked.

speaker: PINTEL
dialogue: Fine.

speaker: BARBOSSA
dialogue: Maid or not, it fits you.

speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogue: Dare I ask the fate of its previous owner?

speaker: BARBOSSA
dialogue: Now, none of that. Please dig in.

speaker: BARBOSSA
dialogue: No need to stand on ceremony, and no call to impress anyone. You must be hungry.

speaker: BARBOSSA
dialogue: Try the wine.

speaker: BARBOSSA
dialogue: And the apples -- one of those next.

speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogue: It's poisoned!

speaker: BARBOSSA
dialogue: Oh, there would be no sense in killing you, Miss Turner.

speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogue: Then why aren't you eating?

speaker: BARBOSSA
dialogue: Would that I could.

speaker: BARBOSSA
dialogue: Do you not know what this is, then?

speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogue: It's a pirate medallion.

speaker: BARBOSSA
dialogue: It's a piece of the treasure of Isla de Muerta.

speaker: BARBOSSA
dialogue: Ah, so you don't know as much as you pretend. Back when Cortes was cutting a great bloody swath through the New World, a high priest gave him all the gold they had, with one condition: that he spare the people's lives. Of course, Cortes being Cortes, he didn't. He'd've made a great pirate, that one.

speaker: BARBOSSA
dialogue: So the priest, with his dying breath, called on the power of the blood of his people, and put on the gold a curse. If anyone took so much as a single piece, as he was compelled by greed, by greed he would be consumed.

speaker: BARBOSSA
dialogue: Within a day of leaving port for Spain, the treasure ship carrying the gold... something went wrong. The ship run aground, every man aboard dead, save one. He survived long enough to hide the gold ashore. Over time, the dark magic of the curse seeped into the place, making it a cursed island. An island of death. Isla de Muerta.

speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogue: That's all very interesting, but I hardly believe in ghost stories any more.

speaker: BARBOSSA
dialogue: You idiot girl! It's no make-believe! My crew and I, we found the gold, and we did more than take one piece, we took it all. Rich men we were and we spent it and traded it and gave it away in exchange for drink and food and pleasant company. But we found out: the drink could not sate us, and the food turned to ashes in our mouths, and no amount of pleasant company could ease our torment. We are cursed men, Miss Turner, condemned, to be forever consumed by our own greed. Gold calls to US, always, and we are driven, always, to find more, and add it to the treasure.

speaker: BARBOSSA
dialogue: There is but one way to remove the curse. All of the scattered pieces of the treasure must be restored in full, and the blood repaid. We've recovered every piece -- save for this. And as for the blood... that's what we have you for. And that's why there's no sense in killing you. Yet.

speaker: BARBOSSA
dialogue: Apple?

speaker: BARBOSSA
dialogue: I'm curious -- after killing me, what is it you were planning to do next?

speaker: BARBOSSA
dialogue: Look! LOOK! The moonlight shows us for what we really are! We are not among the living and so we cannot die --

speaker: BARBOSSA
dialogue: -- but neither are we dead! We have all the desires of the living, but cannot satisfy them! Ten years I have been parched of thirst, and unable to quench it! Ten years, I have been starving to death -- and haven't died! And I have not felt anything for ten years... Not the wind on my face, nor the spray of the sea... ...nor the flesh of a woman...

speaker: BARBOSSA
dialogue: You'd best start believing in ghost stories, Miss Turner. Because now you're in one.

speaker: JACK
dialogue: For a man whose made an industry of avoiding boats, you're a quick study.

speaker: WILL
dialogue: I worked passage from England as a cabin boy. After my mother passed, I came out here... looking for my father.

speaker: JACK
dialogue: Is that so?

speaker: WILL
dialogue: My father. William Turner?

speaker: WILL
dialogue: I'm not a simpleton. At the jail -- it was only after you learned my name that you agreed to help. Since that's what I wanted, I didn't press the matter. But now -- accusation you knew my father.

speaker: JACK
dialogue: I knew him. Probably one of the few who knew him as William Turner. Most everyone just called him Bill, or 'Bootstrap' Bill.

speaker: WILL
dialogue: 'Bootstrap?'

speaker: JACK
dialogue: Good man. Good pirate. And clever. I never met anyone with as clever a mind and hands as him. When you were puzzling out that cell door, it was like seeing his twin.

speaker: WILL
dialogue: That's not true.

speaker: JACK
dialogue: I swear, you look just like him.

speaker: WILL
dialogue: It's not true that my father was a pirate.

speaker: JACK
dialogue: Figured you wouldn't want to hear it.

speaker: WILL
dialogue: He was a merchant marine! He was a respectable man who obeyed the law, and followed the rules--

speaker: JACK
dialogue: You think your father is the only man who ever lived the Glasgow life, telling folk one thing, and then going off to do another? There's quite a few who come here, hoping to amass enough swag to ease the burdens of respectable life. And they're all 'merchant marines.'

speaker: WILL
dialogue: My father did not think of my mother -- his family -- as a burden.

speaker: JACK
dialogue: Sure -- because he could always go pirating.

speaker: WILL
dialogue: My father -- was not -- a pirate!

speaker: JACK
dialogue: Put it away, Will. It's not worth getting beat again.

speaker: WILL
dialogue: You didn't beat me. You ignored the rules of engagement. In a fair fight, I'd kill you.

speaker: JACK
dialogue: Then that's not much incentive for me to fight fair, is it?

speaker: JACK
dialogue: As long as you're just hanging there, pay attention. Must, Should, do, don't, shall, shall not -- those are just suggestions. There are only two absolute rules. What a man can do. And what a man can't do.

speaker: JACK
dialogue: For instance: you can accept that your father was a pirate and still a good man... or you can't. Now me, I can sail this ship to Tortuga, by myself... But I can't just let you drown.

speaker: WILL
dialogue: Tortuga?

speaker: JACK
dialogue: Oh -- did I forget to mention that?

speaker: JACK
dialogue: We need a crew. We can manage the ship between islands, but the open sea, that's another matter --

speaker: WILL
dialogue: Just do it quickly.

speaker: JACK
dialogue: Don't worry. I've already got my Quartermaster -- there!

speaker: ANAMARIA
dialogue: You stole my boat.

speaker: JACK
dialogue: AnaMaria! Have you seen Gibbs? I need to put together --

speaker: JACK
dialogue: Borrowed. Borrowed your boat. Without permission.

speaker: ANAMARIA
dialogue: My dory. The Jolly Mon. Where is it?

speaker: JACK
dialogue: Safe! At Port Royal. With the Royal Navy.

speaker: ANAMARIA
dialogue: That boat is my livelihood!

speaker: JACK
dialogue: You'll get it back. Or one better.

speaker: ANAMARIA
dialogue: I will.

speaker: WILL
dialogue: Jack! Over here!

speaker: WILL
dialogue: He knows Gibbs.

speaker: GIBBS
dialogue: Curse you for breathing, you slack- jawed idiot Mother's love, Jack, you know better than to wake a man when he's sleeping. It's bad luck!

speaker: JACK
dialogue: Well, fortunately, I know how to counter it. The man who did the waking buys the man who was sleeping a drink, and the man who was sleeping it drinks it while listening to a proposition.

speaker: GIBBS
dialogue: Aye, that'll about do it.

speaker: GIBBS
dialogue: Blast it, I'm already awake!

speaker: WILL
dialogue: I know. That was for the smell.

speaker: JACK
dialogue: Just the one.

speaker: GIBBS
dialogue: Make it last, then. Now, what's the nature of this venture of yours?

speaker: JACK
dialogue: First -- have you found me a crew?

speaker: GIBBS
dialogue: Oh, there's a hard tale, Jack. Most of the decent pirates in town won't sail with you -- seem to think you're a jinx.

speaker: JACK
dialogue: Now where, I wonder, would they have gotten that idea?

speaker: JACK
dialogue: I'm going after the Black Pearl.

speaker: GIBBS
dialogue: Say again?

speaker: JACK
dialogue: I'm going after the Black Pearl. I know where its going to be, and I'm going to take it.

speaker: GIBBS
dialogue: Jack, it's a fool's errand: You've heard the tales they tell about the Pearl.

speaker: JACK
dialogue: Aye, and that's why I know where it's going to be, and that's why I know what Barbossa is up to. All I need is a crew.

speaker: GIBBS
dialogue: A fool's errand.

speaker: JACK
dialogue: Not if the fool has something Barbossa wants. Something he needs.

speaker: GIBBS
dialogue: And you've got that, have you?

speaker: JACK
dialogue: Back there, guarding the door is the son of old Bootstrap Bill Turner.

speaker: GIBBS
dialogue: Well, lookee there. I'll allow you may be onto something, Jack. There's bound to be sailors on this rock crazy as you. I'll find some men.

speaker: GIBBS
dialogue: Kid's a bit of a stick, isn't he?

speaker: JACK
dialogue: That he is.

speaker: GIBBS
dialogue: Feast your eyes, Cap'n. All of 'em good sea-faring men, faithful hands before the mast, every one worth his salt -- -- and crazy, to boot.

speaker: ANAMARIA
dialogue: You owe me a boat.

speaker: GIBBS
dialogue: Cotton here is mute, sir. Poor devil had his tongue cut out --

speaker: GIBBS
dialogue: -- so he went and trained the parrot to do the talking for him, nobody knows how. Nobody knows the parrot's name, neither, so we just call it 'Cotton's parrot.'

speaker: JACK
dialogue: Mr. Cotton. Do you have the courage and fortitude to follow orders and stay true, in the face danger, and almost certain death?

speaker: COTTON'S PARROT
dialogue: Wind in your SAILS! Wind in your SAILS!

speaker: GIBBS
dialogue: Mostly, that seem to mean 'yes.'

speaker: JACK
dialogue: That goes for the rest of you! Danger and near certain death. For we are to sail for the Isla de Muerta, to rescue the daughter of Governor Swann. An equal share of the reward shall be --

speaker: WILL
dialogue: Shut up, before you lose them all!

speaker: JACK
dialogue: These are the only ones worth having. And we're going to need them --

speaker: GIBBS
dialogue: That fool will have us lose the canvas, and the masts besides!

speaker: GIBBS
dialogue: We'd best drop canvas, sir!

speaker: JACK
dialogue: She can hold a bit longer.

speaker: GIBBS
dialogue: What's in your head to put you in such a fine mood?

speaker: JACK
dialogue: We're catching up!

speaker: TWIGG
dialogue: Isla de Muerta! Isla de Muerta, off the port bow!

speaker: JACOBY
dialogue: Orders, Captain?

speaker: BARBOSSA
dialogue: Bring her in, not too close. I won't brave the reef, not until high tide. We lay anchor before dark.

speaker: BARBOSSA
dialogue: ...that is, if it first doesn't sink back down to hell from where it came.

speaker: JACK
dialogue: Bear three points starboard.

speaker: JACK
dialogue: Six points port!

speaker: GIBBS
dialogue: Left handed-ropes are coiled against the sun, or it's bad luck! Anty-clockwise.

speaker: WILL
dialogue: How do we expect to find an island no one can find -- with a compass that doesn't work?

speaker: GIBBS
dialogue: Now, lad, just because it don't point north don't mean it don't work. That compass gives bearings to the Isla de Muerta, wherever it may lie.

speaker: WILL
dialogue: Really? So... what's the story on the pistol?

speaker: GIBBS
dialogue: I'll tell you. Now, Jack Sparrow has an honest streak in him, and that's where the whole problem starts. This was when he was Captain of the Black Pearl --

speaker: WILL
dialogue: What? He never told me that.

speaker: GIBBS
dialogue: Ah -- he's learned, then. Plays things more close to the vest. See, Jack was a cartographer, back in Old England. Somehow he came by the money to commission the Pearl. Hired himself a crew, promised each man an equal share. So, they're forty days out, and the First Mate says, everything's an equal share, that should mean the location of the island, too. So Jack gave up the bearings. That night, there was mutiny.

speaker: GIBBS
dialogue: Jack gave hisself up for the sake of his loyal crewmen. He was marooned on an island, left there to die.

speaker: WILL
dialogue: How did he get off the island?

speaker: JACK
dialogue: I didn't!

speaker: JACK
dialogue: My body's still there, rotting away, and I am but a ghost!

speaker: GIBBS
dialogue: How did you get off the island?

speaker: JACK
dialogue: Ah, that's a dark and unpleasant tale, best left untold.

speaker: WILL
dialogue: Wait -- what about the pistol?

speaker: JACK
dialogue: The pistol. When a pirate is marooned, Will, he's given a pistol with a single shot. No good for hunting, or surviving, really. But after three weeks of starvation and thirst -- the option of that pistol begins to look good.

speaker: JACK
dialogue: But I survived. And I still have that single shot. It's meant for one man. My mutinous first mate --

speaker: WILL
dialogue: Barbossa.

speaker: KOEHLER
dialogue: Moonrise, Captain! First night of full.

speaker: BARBOSSA
dialogue: Hah! Be mindful of pits and crevasses. Stay together.

speaker: BARBOSSA
dialogue: Careful, mate. Fall down there, you'd die and miss Judgement Day -- for not even the Lord himself'll come look for you here.

speaker: COTTON'S PARROT
dialogue: Land HO! Land HO! LAND ho! LAND ho!

speaker: ANAMARIA
dialogue: How does he do that?

speaker: JACK
dialogue: They'll be anchored on the lee side. Haul your wind, and keep to the weather of the island --

speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogue: The curse drove you to gather this?

speaker: BARBOSSA (O.S.)
dialogue: Aye. And not a bit of it any use to us, only hoarded. But it will drive us no longer.

speaker: WILL
dialogue: What's that?

speaker: JACK
dialogue: Depends.

speaker: WILL
dialogue: On what?

speaker: JACK
dialogue: On whether the stories are all true. If they are, that's a waterfall that spills over at high tide, with a short drop to an underground lagoon. If not --

speaker: JACK
dialogue: -- well, too late.

speaker: JACK
dialogue: Chalk one up for the stories.

speaker: BARBOSSA
dialogue: Here we stand before the cursed treasure of Cortez himself. Won by blood, it demands blood in return.

speaker: PINTEL
dialogue: What did you expect? We're all gentlemen here, right and proper.

speaker: BARBOSSA
dialogue: You know the first thing I'm going to do after the curse is lifted? Eat a whole bushel of apples.

speaker: BARBOSSA
dialogue: What was begun by blood, let blood now end!

speaker: KOEHLER
dialogue: Did it work?

speaker: DEADEYE
dialogue: I don't feel no different.

speaker: JACOBY
dialogue: How do we tell?

speaker: KOEHLER
dialogue: You're not dead.

speaker: JACOBY
dialogue: No. He shot me!

speaker: TWIGG
dialogue: It didn't work! The curse is still upon us!

speaker: BARBOSSA
dialogue: You. Maid. Your father. What was his name?! Was your father William Turner?!

speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogue: No.

speaker: BARBOSSA
dialogue: Where's his child? The child that sailed from England eight years ago, the child who is the real owner of that medallion, the child in whose veins flows the blood of William Turner?! Where?

speaker: JACOBY
dialogue: You brought us the wrong person!

speaker: PINTEL
dialogue: She had the medallion! She's the right age. She said her name was Turner!

speaker: TWIGG
dialogue: You brought us here for nothing?

speaker: BARBOSSA
dialogue: If you had sailed with Morgan for ten years like I have, you'd know not to question me!

speaker: BARBOSSA
dialogue: If any coward here dare challenge me, let him speak! Any more talk, I'll chain ye to a cannon and send ye to the watery depths!

speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogue: You?!

speaker: JACK
dialogue: Me!

speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogue: You're in league with Barbossa!

speaker: JACK
dialogue: No, I'm -- rescuing you.

speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogue: You?!

speaker: WILL
dialogue: Miss Swann! We're here to rescue you! It's going badly!

speaker: JACK
dialogue: This way!

speaker: WILL
dialogue: I'm glad we got here in time.

speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogue: Truthfully -- you were a bit late.

speaker: JACK
dialogue: The trick isn't getting here, it's getting away.

speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogue: Come on!

speaker: JACK
dialogue: No. This won't work. I'll stay behind, and fight them. You go on.

speaker: WILL
dialogue: No.

speaker: JACK
dialogue: I'll lead them away.

speaker: JACK
dialogue: Go to the opposite end of the island, and signal the ship. I'll keep 'em busy.

speaker: WILL
dialogue: Are you sure? Jack -- this is not something you have to do.

speaker: JACK
dialogue: I'm sure. When you've led the kind of life I have, there are debts that must be paid. Maybe I can balance the scales a little.

speaker: JACK
dialogue: I invoke the right of parlay, according to the Code of the Brethren, set down by the pirates Morgan and Bartholomew...

speaker: BARBOSSA
dialogue: I'm inclined to kill you now, Jack Sparrow, without so much as a word, if you don't lose that grin from your face.

speaker: JACK
dialogue: The woman's blood didn't work, did it?

speaker: JACK
dialogue: I know who's blood you need, to end the curse.

speaker: BARBOSSA
dialogue: Say the name, or I slit your throat.

speaker: JACK
dialogue: No you won't.

speaker: PINTEL
dialogue: Now?

speaker: BARBOSSA
dialogue: Now. No, don't kill him.

speaker: BARBOSSA
dialogue: Allow me the humor of listening to your terms.

speaker: JACK
dialogue: Simple. I have something you want more than anything. The way to free you from the curse of the treasure. You have something I want -- more than anything.

speaker: BARBOSSA
dialogue: The Pearl? Oh, that's fine. And just how do you expect this to work?

speaker: JACK
dialogue: You give me the Pearl. Then I tell you who you need.

speaker: BARBOSSA
dialogue: That's your offer? You, sailing away nice and pretty with the Black Pearl, and all I have is a name?

speaker: JACK
dialogue: That's right.

speaker: BARBOSSA
dialogue: I'm supposed to... trust you?

speaker: JACK
dialogue: I'm a man of my word.

speaker: JACK
dialogue: You see, I've got this honest streak in me -- in its own way, a sort of curse. Oh, and there's the fact that you have no choice.

speaker: BARBOSSA
dialogue: I'll torture it out of you.

speaker: JACK
dialogue: You left me on a desert island -- what worse can you do?

speaker: BARBOSSA
dialogue: Blast you! I'll throw you in prison.

speaker: JACK
dialogue: Wait as long as you like.

speaker: BARBOSSA
dialogue: You're setting me up for a double cross, you with the ship, and me with nothing more than your word!

speaker: JACK
dialogue: Let's say I tell you the wrong person. What would you do?

speaker: BARBOSSA
dialogue: Track you down and --

speaker: JACK
dialogue: And if I tell you the truth, you become mortal, and you won't come near me because you know I'd kill you.

speaker: BARBOSSA
dialogue: Jack, I don't trust you, and that's a fact. Never trust a smiling man, you can lay to that.

speaker: JACK
dialogue: See, that's where we're different. I trust you... to do what it takes to get what you want.

speaker: BARBOSSA
dialogue: You're playing this as close to the edge as any man, I'll give you that. We might just have to sign articles, you and I. Jack, you're a pirate at heart, that's certain.

speaker: BARBOSSA
dialogue: Pintel... set sail. If this fool plan is to work, we'll need the medallion, and that means catching the ship which brought 'em here.

speaker: JACK
dialogue: What -- you don't have the medallion?

speaker: BARBOSSA
dialogue: That fool woman took it. You be careful around her, Jack -- she's pretty enough, she'll steal your heart -- but pure evil inside.

speaker: JACK
dialogue: I'll watch my back.

speaker: BARBOSSA
dialogue: Bosun! Set up Mr. Sparrow's quarters, nice and fine... in the brig. Meaning no disrespect, of course.

speaker: GIBBS
dialogue: Two women on board? A man don't have to be superstitious to know that's trouble.

speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogue: ...you were in danger... so I took the medallion. And I've kept it ever since. They thought I was you, that they needed my blood. And it didn't work.

speaker: WILL
dialogue: Why would my father send this to me?

speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogue: To keep it away from them? No pirate would sail to London, for fear of Execution Dock.

speaker: WILL
dialogue: If I had known --

speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogue: -- then we never would have met.

speaker: WILL
dialogue: I can't believe he would make such a sacrifice for us.

speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogue: I guess you can never truly know someone else's heart.

speaker: GIBBS
dialogue: Shift your heading, steer clear of that island. Fifteen degrees starboard.

speaker: COTTON'S PARROT
dialogue: Dead men tell NO tales! Dead men tell NO tales! Dead men tell NO tales!

speaker: ANAMARIA
dialogue: Can we outrun them?

speaker: GIBBS
dialogue: Not a chance. Make for the reef.

speaker: PINTEL
dialogue: What's he doing? Is he going to run her aground?

speaker: GIBBS
dialogue: Drop the forward anchor!

speaker: BARBOSSA
dialogue: All hands! Prepare to come about!

speaker: JACK
dialogue: Don't hit my ship! I mean, kill the lying scoundrel -- I'm a little conflicted, here.

speaker: BARBOSSA
dialogue: Strike your colors, you bloody cockroaches!

speaker: ANAMARIA
dialogue: Looks like they mean to send us under.

speaker: GIBBS
dialogue: There -- she's raised the Jolly Roger, upside down.

speaker: GIBBS (CONT 'D)
dialogue: It's a signal. If we resist, it won't just be death. There'll be torture as well.

speaker: WILL
dialogue: We're not going to just surrender!

speaker: GIBBS
dialogue: That we are.

speaker: WILL
dialogue: We can at least fight -- we might be able to kill a few --

speaker: GIBBS
dialogue: Will -- it'll go worse for us -- for Elizabeth, especially -- if we fight.

speaker: BARBOSSA
dialogue: Welcome back, Miss. Last time on board, you played me right clever, make pretending and all. I hope your stay this time is more pleasant. Boys, show her some hospitality!

speaker: WILL
dialogue: She goes free!

speaker: BARBOSSA
dialogue: What's in your head, boy?

speaker: WILL
dialogue: She. Goes. Free.

speaker: BARBOSSA
dialogue: You've got one shot -- and we can't die.

speaker: WILL
dialogue: You can't. I can.

speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogue: No!

speaker: JACK
dialogue: Will -- don't do anything stupid! Don't say anything stupid --

speaker: WILL
dialogue: My name is Will Turner, the son of Bootstrap Bill Turner. His blood runs in my veins. You need my blood. And on my word I will pull this trigger, and sink all the way down to Davy Jones' Locker!

speaker: TWIGG
dialogue: It's true -- he's the spittin' image of old Bootstrap. Even talks the same!

speaker: BARBOSSA
dialogue: Looks like you're back to having nothing to offer.

speaker: PINTEL
dialogue: And he's got Old Bill's courage. A curse on him, and you!

speaker: BARBOSSA
dialogue: Enough of that! Name your terms.

speaker: WILL
dialogue: Elizabeth goes free!

speaker: BARBOSSA
dialogue: We got that part. Anything else?

speaker: WILL
dialogue: And Jack. And the crew. Free and unharmed. If you agree... then... I will remain with you.

speaker: BARBOSSA
dialogue: Agreed. You have my word, as a gentleman of fortune --

speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogue: Will -- you can't trust him.

speaker: WILL
dialogue: You must swear by the Holy Bible.

speaker: BARBOSSA
dialogue: Eh? You have my word, then -- on the Good Book, I do swear, and the Lord spare my worthless soul.

speaker: BARBOSSA
dialogue: Boatswain! Take your captives below decks. Chain them in the galley, and teach 'em how to row.

speaker: BARBOSSA
dialogue: Hah. Look there. That's the very same island we made Jack governor of on our last trip. When you sail the open sea as long as I, you learn to trust the signs fate sends your way.

speaker: GIBBS
dialogue: Amen to that...

speaker: BARBOSSA
dialogue: Jack, Elizabeth... I'm a man of my word and you're to be set free, right quick. Men, break out the plank!

speaker: WILL
dialogue: No! You gave your word!

speaker: BARBOSSA
dialogue: Quiet, boy, or you'll lose your tongue. Those as know me know I wouldn't cross my word, and bring down bad luck on the ship. I agreed to set them free. I didn't say when... nor where.

speaker: JACK
dialogue: It's pure evil to make a Captain walk the plank of his own ship, twice in one lifetime. No good can come of it.

speaker: BARBOSSA
dialogue: Now, Jack. That reef is less than a league distant. It's a square deal all around, and you can't hope for better.

speaker: JACK
dialogue: Someone needs to cut these bonds, then.

speaker: BARBOSSA
dialogue: You'd best take a swim, Jack.

speaker: JACK
dialogue: The last time you did this, you left me a pistol, with one shot.

speaker: PINTEL
dialogue: That's proper, sir, according to the code.

speaker: BARBOSSA
dialogue: By the Powers, you're right! Where's Jack's pistol? Who's got it? Bring it forward!

speaker: JACK
dialogue: A gentleman might give us two pistols, seeing as there are two of us, this time.

speaker: BARBOSSA
dialogue: Tell you what. I'll give you one pistol, and let you be the gentleman, an' shoot the lady, and starve to death yourself! That is, presuming you're not both drownded.

speaker: BARBOSSA (CONTID)
dialogue: So how did you get off that island, anyway?

speaker: JACK
dialogue: You can go to your grave not knowing.

speaker: BARBOSSA
dialogue: That's fair.

speaker: BARBOSSA
dialogue: The lady's next. But first, I'll be wanting that dress back, if you please.

speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogue: Here -- it will go well with your black heart !

speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogue: I will not walk into the ocean. You'll have to throw me in!

speaker: BARBOSSA
dialogue: Have at her, lads!

speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogue: You went back for that? We need to head for the reef!

speaker: JACK
dialogue: That's the second time I've had to watch that man sail away with my ship.

speaker: JACK (O.S.)
dialogue: Not all that big, is it?

speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogue: Has it changed since the last time you were here?

speaker: JACK
dialogue: The trees are taller.

speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogue: I hope you have no intention of using that.

speaker: JACK
dialogue: Not yet. Ask me again in a few weeks.

speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogue: Captain Sparrow! We have to get off this island -- immediately!

speaker: JACK
dialogue: Don't be thinking I'm not already working on it.

speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogue: What is that? Is there a boat under there?

speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogue: What? What's wrong? How will this help us get off the island?

speaker: JACK
dialogue: It won't. It won't, and so we won't.

speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogue: But... you did it before! Last time --

speaker: JACK
dialogue: Last time, I was here a grand total of three days. Last time, the rumrunners who used this island as a cache came by, and I bartered passage off.

speaker: JACK
dialogue: But from the looks of this, they've long been out of business, and so that won't be happening again. We probably have your friend Norrington to thank for that.

speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogue: So that's it? That's the secret grand adventure of the infamous Jack Sparrow? You spent three days on the beach drinking rum?

speaker: JACK
dialogue: Welcome to the Caribbean, love.

speaker: JACK
dialogue: You should look at our contretemps this way: we've got shade trees, thank the Lord. We've got some food on the trees, thank the Lord again. And we've got rum, praise the Lord. We can stay alive a month, maybe more. Keep a weather eye open for passing ships, and our chances are fair.

speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogue: A month? Will doesn't have a month! We've got to do something to help him!

speaker: JACK
dialogue: You're right. Here's luck to you, Will Turner.

speaker: JACK
dialogue: Don't be thinking I'm happy about this, Elizabeth. But I see no use in wailing and gnashing my teeth over that which I can do nothing about.

speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogue: Not when you can drink instead, at least.

speaker: JACK
dialogue: Try it. It goes down rough, but it goes down -- and the second swig goes down easier.

speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogue: And you will call me Miss Swann.

speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogue: Drink up me hearties, yo ho...

speaker: JACK
dialogue: What? What was that? Something funny, Miss Swann? share. PLEASE.

speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogue: Nothing... it's nothing. Just... I'm reminded of a song I learned as a child. A song about pirates.

speaker: JACK
dialogue: I know a lot of songs about pirates, but none I'd teach a child. Let's hear it.

speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogue: Oh, no... it's silly. Back in England we didn't know a thing about pirates, really. They seemed so romantic and daring --

speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogue: That was before I met one, of course.

speaker: JACK
dialogue: Now I must hear this song. An authentic pirate song. Have at it.

speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogue: Well, perhaps... with a bit more to drink, I might...

speaker: JACK
dialogue: More to drink!

speaker: JACK
dialogue: Well?

speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogue: We pillage, we plunder, we rifle, we loot, Drink up me hearties, yo ho.

speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogue: We kidnap and ravage and we don't give a hoot, Drink up me hearties, yo ho --

speaker: JACK / ELIZABETH
dialogue: Yo ho, yo ho, a pirate's life for me! Yo ho, yo ho, it's a pirates life for me!

speaker: JACK
dialogue: I LOVE this song! Yo ho, yo ho, a pirate's life for me! We're beggars and blighters, ne'er do well cads, Drink up me hearties, yo ho! Aye but we're loved by our mums and our dads. Drink up me hearties, yo ho!

speaker: JACK
dialogue: When I get the Black Pearl back, I'm going to teach it to the whole crew, and we'll sing it all the time!

speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogue: You'll be positively the most fearsome pirates to sail the Spanish Main.

speaker: JACK
dialogue: Not just the Spanish Main. The whole ocean... the whole world. Wherever we want to go, we go. That's what a ship is, you know. Not just a keel and a hull and a deck and sails. That's what a ship need... but what a ship is -- what the Black Pearl really is... is freedom.

speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogue: Jack, it must be so terrible for you, to be trapped here on this island, all over again.

speaker: JACK
dialogue: Ah, well... the company is better than last time. And the scenery has definitely improved.

speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogue: Mr. Sparrow! I'm not sure I've had enough rum to allow that kind of talk.

speaker: JACK
dialogue: We've got a few bottles left... and we've yet to tap the kegs.

speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogue: To freedom.

speaker: JACK
dialogue: To the Black Pearl.

speaker: JACK
dialogue: What are you doing? You've burned our food, the shade -- the rum!

speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogue: Yes, the rum is gone.

speaker: JACK
dialogue: Why?

speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogue: One, because it is a vile drink that turns even the most respectable men into scoundrels. Two --

speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogue: That signal is over a thousand feet high, which means it can be seen for two hundred leagues in every direction.

speaker: JACK
dialogue: You -- you burned up the island, for a one-time chance at being spotted?

speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogue: Exactly.

speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogue: Just you wait, Captain. In an hour, maybe two, keep a 'weather eye open' and you'll be seeing white sails on that horizon!

speaker: JACK
dialogue: They'll be no living with her after this.

speaker: NORRINGTON
dialogue: Elizabeth, I'm relieved you're safe. Clap him in irons. And behind his back this time.

speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogue: Commodore, you can't do that!

speaker: NORRINGTON
dialogue: You're speaking up for him again?

speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogue: He can locate Isla de Muerta -- but I doubt he'll be willing to help us from the brig.

speaker: JACK
dialogue: We had time to get to know each other.

speaker: NORRINGTON
dialogue: We are bound for Port Royal, not Isla de Muerta.

speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogue: No. The pirates have taken Will --

speaker: NORRINGTON
dialogue: Your father is frantic with worry. Our mission was to rescue you and return home. That is what we shall do. Mr. Turner's fate is regrettable. But so was his decision to engage in piracy.

speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogue: Commodore, please!

speaker: JACK
dialogue: Norrington, think about it... the Black Pearl, its captain and crew... the last pirate threat in the Caribbean. How can you pass that up?

speaker: NORRINGTON
dialogue: By remembering that I serve others, not only myself.

speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogue: Commodore, I beg you -- please do this... for me. As a wedding gift.

speaker: NORRINGTON
dialogue: I am to understand that you will accept my marriage proposal on the condition I rescue Mr. Turner?

speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogue: Not as a condition -- a request.

speaker: NORRINGTON
dialogue: Free Mister Sparrow, and prepare to come about. He'll give you our heading.

speaker: JACK
dialogue: Congratulations, sir.

speaker: NORRINGTON
dialogue: Elizabeth, I hereby withdraw my proposal.

speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogue: What?

speaker: NORRINGTON
dialogue: I know now where your heart truly lies.

speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogue: And now I know... where yours does, as well.

speaker: NORRINGTON
dialogue: You may seclude yourself in my cabin. I'm afraid we do not have any ladies' clothing aboard.

speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogue: Then I can wear men's clothing.

speaker: NORRINGTON
dialogue: That would hardly be proper.

speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogue: Well, I am not going to stay hidden in a some cabin. I suppose it's going to be heaving bosoms and bare ankles for the remainder of the voyage!

speaker: NORRINGTON
dialogue: Murtogg, take our guest below, and find her some trousers, and a shirt.

speaker: PINTEL
dialogue: That ain't going to work. That's the gun deck above yea.

speaker: WILL
dialogue: What happened to William Turner?

speaker: PINTEL
dialogue: Ah, William Turner. Stupid blighter. He threw in with us after we relieved Jack Sparrow of his captaincy, but turned out, it never sat well with him particularly after we found Cortes' treasure, and its peculiar condition. He thought we deserved to be cursed, for leaving ol' Jack to the fate we did. That's why he sent off a piece of the treasure -- to you, as it were: so it would never be recovered, and so cursed we remain.

speaker: WILL
dialogue: And then he ran. And he's hiding out someplace where you haven't been able to find him.

speaker: PINTEL
dialogue: That's a nice thought, to be sure, and I wager your da wishes he'd thought it hisself. But, no. See, what he'd done, didn't sit too well with Captain Barbossa... so he chained a cannon to his legs and dumped him over.

speaker: PINTEL
dialogue: Yep, last I saw of Bootstrap Bill, was his face looking up, as he sank down to the crushing black oblivion of Davy Jones' locker. It was only after, we found out we needed his blood to solve the curse. That's what you call ironic.

speaker: BARBOSSA
dialogue: Bring him.

speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogue: You didn't tell Commodore Norrington everything.

speaker: JACK
dialogue: Nor did you, I noticed.

speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogue: He might delay the rescue... and that would be too late.

speaker: JACK
dialogue: Exactly.

speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogue: These men will be facing an enemy that seemingly cannot be killed.

speaker: JACK
dialogue: I have a plan. If it succeeds, then any battle will be decidedly brief... and one-sided.

speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogue: What's your plan?

speaker: LOOKOUT (O.S.)
dialogue: LAND HO!

speaker: NORRINGTON
dialogue: Elizabeth -- below decks. I will not compromise your safety.

speaker: NORRINGTON
dialogue: Lieutenant, escort Elizabeth to my quarters, and make sure she stays there.

speaker: NORRINGTON
dialogue: I don't like the situation, mister Sparrow. The island is riddled with caves. I will not put my men at a disadvantage.

speaker: JACK
dialogue: Funny, I was thinking along those lines. How about you let me go in alone, and while you're setting up an ambush, I'll trick the pirates out to you.

speaker: NORRINGTON
dialogue: You would do that?

speaker: JACK
dialogue: They left me stranded. Twice. What have you got to lose?

speaker: NORRINGTON
dialogue: Nothing I wouldn't be pleased to be rid of.

speaker: JACK
dialogue: I knew you'd listen to reason!

speaker: JACK
dialogue: That chart I drew up'll get you past the reefs. If you're steersman's good enough, that is.

speaker: NORRINGTON
dialogue: I'll be at the wheel myself.

speaker: JACK
dialogue: I'll slip in, talk them into to coming out, and you'll be free to blow holy high heaven the whole lot of them.

speaker: PINTEL
dialogue: No reason to fret. It's just a prick of the finger and a few drops of blood.

speaker: BARBOSSA
dialogue: Turner blood doesn't flow pure in his veins. Best play it safe, and spill it all.

speaker: PINTEL
dialogue: I guess there is a reason to fret.

speaker: BARBOSSA
dialogue: Careful, now. You could fall in and still be wonder'n when you'll hit dirt.

speaker: WILL
dialogue: You deserve to be cursed -- and remain cursed!

speaker: BARBOSSA
dialogue: Blast him! A pox on him, and his father, and the whole damnable line! Fan out! Find him!

speaker: COTTON'S PARROT
dialogue: Drink UP me hearties yo ho! Drink UP me hearties yo ho!

speaker: JACK
dialogue: Do you have any idea where you're going?

speaker: WILL
dialogue: Jack!

speaker: JACK
dialogue: Don't talk. These caves magnify sound. Just follow me.

speaker: WILL
dialogue: Are you certain this is the right way?

speaker: JACK
dialogue: It's the right way.

speaker: BARBOSSA
dialogue: Thank you, Jack Sparrow.

speaker: BARBOSSA
dialogue: You couldn't have led him back more directly if you knew exactly where you were going.

speaker: WILL
dialogue: You did know where you were going! You did lead us directly to them! Why?

speaker: BARBOSSA
dialogue: What was begun by blood, let blood now end!

speaker: JACK
dialogue: You don't want to be doing that.

speaker: BARBOSSA
dialogue: No, I really think I do.

speaker: JACK
dialogue: All right then.

speaker: BARBOSSA
dialogue: Why don't I want to do this?

speaker: JACK
dialogue: Because, right about now, the H.M.S. Dauntless is lying in wait in the harbor.

speaker: WILL
dialogue: Jack!

speaker: JACK
dialogue: -- and its guns and crew will cut you and your men to pieces the moment you step outside these caves.

speaker: PINTEL
dialogue: Do you believe him?

speaker: BARBOSSA
dialogue: No. But him I believe. He is genuinely angry.

speaker: JACK
dialogue: You've no hope of surviving Norrington's attack... that is, if you're mortal.

speaker: BARBOSSA
dialogue: What're you suggesting?

speaker: JACK
dialogue: Simple. Don't kill the boy yet. Wait for a more opportune moment.

speaker: JACK
dialogue: Like after you've killed... Every... Last... One... of Norrington's men.

speaker: BARBOSSA
dialogue: I can't help wondering, Jack, why you're being so helpful and all? Last time you did that, it didn't end well for you.

speaker: JACK
dialogue: The situation has changed.

speaker: BARBOSSA
dialogue: That so?

speaker: JACK
dialogue: Aye. See, after you're done with the Royal Navy, you'll have a bit of a problem: the H.M.S. Dauntless. There you'll be, with two lovely ships on your hands, and what to do? Of course you'll decide you deserve the bigger one, and who's to argue? The Dauntless a first-rate ship-of-line, and with it, you can rule the seas. But if you're Captain of the Dauntless, who's left for the Black Pearl?

speaker: JACK
dialogue: I sail for you as part of your fleet, I give you fifteen percent of my plunder, and you get to introduce yourself at tea parties and brothels as 'Commodore Barbossa.' Do we have an accord?

speaker: JACK
dialogue: Now, you can take care of the Dauntless, right?

speaker: BARBOSSA
dialogue: Men! Are you up for it?

speaker: BARBOSSA
dialogue: Mr. Pintel, select five men to stay here. Take the rest of the men out... not through the caves.

speaker: JACK
dialogue: There's... another exit?

speaker: BARBOSSA
dialogue: Aye, for us there is.

speaker: TALL SAILOR
dialogue: Ship rats. Big ones.

speaker: SHORT SAILOR
dialogue: Hate those things.

speaker: SHORT SAILOR
dialogue: Taste all right, though.

speaker: TALL SAILOR
dialogue: That they do.

speaker: PINTEL
dialogue: Be quick, now. Train the starboard guns on the beach, and set your aim. Wait for my signal, we don't want to spook them.

speaker: SKINNY
dialogue: Which would you prefer first, good sir -- rum, or wine?

speaker: BIG-BONES
dialogue: I believe I'll have a spot o' rum, if you don't mind, and thank'ee kind sir!

speaker: GILLETTE
dialogue: All the men in place, sir. Ready to fire.

speaker: NORRINGTON
dialogue: Wait for my order -- what the blazes is that?

speaker: NORRINGTON
dialogue: Men! Take cover!

speaker: WILL
dialogue: You've been planning this from the beginning. Since you learned my name.

speaker: JACK
dialogue: Oh, please -- do I really seem that clever?

speaker: JACK
dialogue: Use it well.

speaker: BARBOSSA
dialogue: Confound it, Jack -- I was actually beginning to like you!

speaker: NORRINGTON
dialogue: Steady, men! Remember -- we're the Navy!

speaker: NORRINGTON
dialogue: What is happening out there?

speaker: GILLETTE
dialogue: They're on our side! Take heart, men!

speaker: BARBOSSA
dialogue: Just so you know, Jack -- I don't think you're that clever. I think you're a fool. A mortal fool.

speaker: JACK
dialogue: Remarkable how often those two traits coincide.

speaker: BARBOSSA
dialogue: You can't beat me, Jack.

speaker: WILL
dialogue: Jack!

speaker: JACK
dialogue: Well, isn't that interesting.

speaker: JACK
dialogue: They're so pretty, I just couldn't resist stealing one. It's a curse, I guess.

speaker: BARBOSSA
dialogue: So what now, Jack Sparrow? Are we to be two immortals, locked in epic battle until the trumpets of Judgment Day?

speaker: JACK
dialogue: Or you could surrender.

speaker: BARBOSSA
dialogue: Or I could chain you to a cannonball and drop you in the deepest part of the ocean, where you can contemplate your folly forever.

speaker: BARBOSSA
dialogue: Hah. Ten years you carried that pistol, and you end up wasting your shot.

speaker: WILL
dialogue: He didn't waste it.

speaker: WILL
dialogue: Well, you're the worst pirate I've ever heard of. You're a man who can be trusted, who can be counted on, and who can not betray his friends. What kind of pirate is that?

speaker: JACK
dialogue: The worst. On the other hand, maybe I'm a man who can't pass up a chance for revenge against the black-hearted bastard who stole my ship and left me to die in the middle of the ocean -- twice! -- and who knows how to get what he wants. Now that's a great pirate.

speaker: WILL
dialogue: Let's get out of here.

speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogue: You're all right!

speaker: WILL
dialogue: Miss Swann -- are you wearing trousers? And how did you get off the island?

speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogue: Yes, I am wearing trousers. And as for how we got off the island -- ah, that's a grand adventure, but now is not the time to talk about it.

speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogue: There. And don't you dare tell me that wasn't a proper kiss!

speaker: WILL
dialogue: Elizabeth, I think it doesn't matter that we are of a different class --

speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogue: It doesn't!

speaker: WILL
dialogue: -- but that was not a proper kiss.

speaker: WILL
dialogue: This is a proper kiss.

speaker: JACK
dialogue: Tough luck. I was rooting for you.

speaker: NORRINGTON
dialogue: ...and though I do say so with regret, the law is clear. The penalty for piracy is death by hanging.

speaker: SWANN
dialogue: By your leave, I wish to speak on behalf of the boy. It is clear that these deeds were performed out of a sincere desire to do good, at great personal risk. It seems to me, that in the rare occasion where the right course is committing an act of piracy, then an act of piracy is the right course! So in my capacity as Governor, I intend to grant a pardon to --

speaker: GILLETTE
dialogue: Sir!

speaker: GILLETTE
dialogue: Jack and his crew have escaped! There was no damage to the cell... They must have been set free.

speaker: SWANN
dialogue: The Black Pearl!

speaker: GILLETTE
dialogue: Sir! Shall I break out the cannons?

speaker: NORRINGTON
dialogue: I don't think that will be necessary.

speaker: NORRINGTON
dialogue: A day's head start. That's all he gets.

speaker: ANAMARIA
dialogue: Captain Sparrow -- the Black Pearl is yours!

speaker: JACK
dialogue: AnaMaria, trim the mainsail!

speaker: ANAMARIA
dialogue: Aye, aye, sir!

speaker: JACK
dialogue: Mr. Gibbs, organize a cleaning detail -- you and Cotton. I want every inch of the Pearl spic-and-span and ship- shape!
